JORDAN VALLEY WATER CONSERVANCY DISTRICT

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY





Revised: May 26, 2004



1.    Facility description and regulated substance handled:



The Jordan Valley Water Treatment Plant (JVWTP) is located at 15305 South 3200 West, Bluffdale, UT, and is owned and operated by Jordan Valley Water Conservancy District (District).  JVWTP is a conventional treatment process utilizing coagulation, flocculation, sedimentation and filtration.  JVWTP uses chlorine for both pre- and post-disinfection as part of the treatment process.  Disinfection is required for all treated surface waters before being distributed for human consumption.



Liquid chlorine is shipped to JVWTP in one-ton containers, and fed as a gas into the process.  JVWTP normally maintains a chlorine inventory of approximately 16,000 lbs with a maximum possible inventory of 32,000 lbs.  JVWTP is staffed 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, and the facility is equipped with appropriate chlorine detection, alarm, and scrubber systems.  All chlorine related equipment is routinely inspected and serviced.



2.    Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:



The District has outlined a policy in an effort to protect the health and safety of employees and the public by minimizing the risk from exposure to hazardous chemicals.  All employees at the JVWTP are required to comply with the procedures outlined in the PSM/RMP Plan and Chemical Spill Emergency Response Plan.  Management has outlined their commitment to safety in Section 11.7 of the JVWCD Personnel Rules and Regulations Manual:



A.     The personal safety and health of each District employee is of the highest importance.  The District is committed to maintaining an occupational injury-free and illness-free workplace in compliance with all applicable State and federal statutes and regulations.  To this end, the District will provide all the necessary safety equipment and provisions required for personal safety and health

.





3.    General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:



The quantity of chlorine stored at JVWTP exceeds the 2,500 lb threshold established by EPA, making JVWTP subject to Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations.  In addition, JVWTP is also subject to the Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations established by OSHA.  The RMP program is very similar to the prevention program required to comply with OSHA?s PSM requirements.  The purpose of the PSM and RPM is to prevent a catastrophic release of chlorine, or to minimize the consequences should a release ever occur.  The program includes the following items specific to chlorine system: process safety information; a process hazard analysis; operation, maintenance, and training procedures; a review of mechanical integrity; procedures regarding visitors, contractors, and tours; changes to the process; and incident investigations.



Documentation of the management system defines the staffing and organization of JVWTP and states that the Treatment Department Manager has overall responsibility for the implementation of the RMP.  It also defines the delegation of responsibility for specific program elements.



JVWTP personnel have conducted a hazard assessment of facilities, to determine potential risks.  In addition, JVWTP personnel regularly conduct operation and maintenance training, routinely inspect equipment, and regularly perform maintenance of chlorination facilities and equipment.



JVWTP is equipped with a chlorine scrubber system designed to mitigate any release inside the chlorine room.





4.    Five-year accident history:



There have been zero reportable incidents resulting in major injury, death, or damage at JVWTP since construction of the facility including the 5 years preceding the date of this document.



5.    Emergency response program:



JVWTP maintains an emergency response plan which includes evacuation/shelter procedures, notification procedures, and pr

ocedures to account for employees and visitors.  The plan also includes updated personnel information for emergency response team members and outside agencies including their duties and responsibilities.  The emergency response plan has been coordinated with Salt Lake County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), and other local fire departments.  Should there be a need for outside agency assistance, these agencies are  prepared to assist with any medical needs, traffic control, or evacuation/sheltering of the public which may be required.



The procedures and policies outlined regarding the chlorine process, emergency response, and training found in the PSM/RMP document will be reviewed regularly.  All recommendations will be evaluated, and those deemed necessary will be implemented as soon as is reasonably possible.  This is to ensure the safest possible environment for JVWTP employees and the public.



The hazard assessment included a determination of the off-site consequences for both the worst-case and alternate-case leak scenarios.  The distance traveled by a release in these scenarios was determined by EPA?s RMP Comp program.



6.    Planned changes to improve safety:



The chlorination facilities at JVWTP will be modified during 2004/2005 to change from a pressurized system to a vacuum system.  The modifications will include improved automation and control to minimize the potential for a leak and reduce potential risks to JVWTP personnel and the public.  The Risk Management Plan will be updated at that time to document the management of change.
